Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating Students' Learning and Attitudes in a Virtual Chemistry Laboratory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is investigating the benefits of students performing simulated chemistry laboratory experiments in the 3D immersive virtual world of Second Life. Researchers at Florida Institute of Technology are creating the environment and the virtual laboratories which are realistic, fully interactive simulations of their real world analogues. The project is engaging multiple sections of students enrolled in General Chemistry 1 Laboratory at Texas A&M University to complete several weeks of lab activities in Second Life to complement the remainder of their lab course experiences which are traditional. Other sections of students will conduct only traditional laboratory experiences. The two sections are completing identical or nearly identical experiences whether in the traditional lab or the virtual environment. The investigators are answering two research questions: (i) How does the traditional or virtual laboratory environment affect students' ability to achieve the learning goals of the laboratory experiment, including knowledge and kinesthetic skills? (ii) How does the laboratory environment affect students' attitudes towards learning chemistry in the laboratory and performing laboratory work?

This project is providing understanding of students' attitudes and content knowledge of general chemistry laboratory activities performed in a traditional manner as compared to that performed in an online virtual world that also embraces social interactions. By the use of an on-line practicum, offered to all students regardless of the learning cohort in which they participated, the project is measuring students' gains in kinesthetic ("hands-on") laboratory skills.

Prior research suggests that virtual laboratory experiences lead to more favorable opinions of chemistry by students, and to better academic performance. Verification of this outcome can have a transformative effect on the way introductory chemistry laboratories are taught. With challenged budgets and expanding populations, other institutions of higher education may be interested in adapting the Virtual Laboratory approach into their own curriculum. Results from this project could help improve the outcomes of on-line and distance education approaches. The virtual laboratory with its integrated social aspects, is providing more students, and students of underrepresented groups, with access to high quality laboratory education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the first time, hundreds of college students performed introductory chemistry laboratory experiments in the virtual world of Second Life. The accompanying image shows part of the virtual laboratory used in this study. Project leaders collected interviews and opinion surveys of student participants and laboratory instructors in order to find out how they viewed using the virtual world for chemistry education. Students’ grades showed how well they learned the concepts and procedures for the lab experiments. The project spanned two years and was a collaboration between Texas A&M University and Florida Institute of Technology.

            We learned important lessons about how to organize and design laboratory activities in a virtual world. For instance, student training prior to class is essential – they cannot just learn as they go along. A chemistry laboratory, even a virtual one, is a complicated place where students need to focus on the task at hand rather than be distracted by learning to use the computer interface. Interestingly, lab instructors felt a need to adjust their teaching techniques in the virtual world experiments. At times, there is less for the instructors to do since the students can work more independently in a virtual world than in a real world lab. Although the needs of the students are most important in the classroom, concerns of the instructor should not be ignored.

            Based on the data analyzed to date, we have found that the virtual world of Second Life provides a platform for quality laboratory education to students. Students performing experiments in Second Life learn just as much as students who perform similar experiments in a real laboratory. This includes content knowledge measured using pre- and post-experiment quizzes. Students completed a laboratory practicum which measured their abilities to assemble an apparatus which they had used in an experiment performed in either the real or virtual world. Both groups demonstrated equivalent performances in the practicum exercise, demonstrating that students can also learn hands-on skills in a virtual world. Students enjoyed their experience in the virtual lab and found the environment less stressful and less distracting than a real world laboratory.

            Although students involved in this project were attending on-campus classes, learning in virtual worlds is well-suited for online learning as well. Given the widespread access to the internet, students enrolled in economically disadvantaged schools could gain a high-quality science education by performing experiments in a virtual laboratory. Women comprise the majority of students enrolled in online courses and they are underrepresented in science and engineering fields. A positive, educational experience in a virtual laboratory course could encourage online students to study and appreciate science and engineering. Outcomes of this project will help educators design better virtual world experiences. We also hope that these positive results will encourage other educators to explore the use of virtual worlds and virtual reality for their classes.
